Press Release
Texas Man Sentenced to 90 Consecutive Life Sentences for 2019 Mass Shooting at Walmart in El Paso, Texas, Killing 23 People and Injuring 22 Others
==================================================================================================================================================
*   |
Friday, July 7, 2023
Share!
*   
*   
*   
*   
**For Immediate Release**
Office of Public Affairs
A Texas man was sentenced to 90 consecutive life sentences in prison for carrying out a mass shooting at the Cielo Vista Walmart in El Paso, Texas, on Aug. 3, 2019, killing 23 people and injuring 22 more.
On Feb. 8, Patrick Wood Crusius, 24, pleaded guilty to a 90-count indictment with 45 counts of violating the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act and 45 counts of using a firearm during and in relation to crimes of violence...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) is the federal executive department of the U.S. government responsible for the enforcement of the law and administration of justice. They publish official information related to crime statistics, federal investigations, and legal standards. Due to its authoritative role, the DOJ is highly reliable and provides accurate, evidence-based information. However, government sites can vary in specific real-time news coverage, so a minor deduction is made.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence pertains to a mass shooting case in Texas and has no relevance to the assault on Christopher Marquez. It provides information about a completely different incident and does not mention any suspects or affiliations related to Marquez's case.

Query1.title: When police don't believe a sexual assault report
Query1.snippet: Mar 11, 2023 ... An illustration shows a police officer crossing off the word victim and writing suspect as an Credit: Illustration by Molly Mendoza. Nicole ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... found in my research. I began looking into cases just like Nicole several years ago, where an alleged victim of sexual assault becomes the suspect and is charged with crimes like false reporting. I looked closely at 52 cases, and I saw patterns emerge, like 15 cases were decided in a day. Once police find inaccuracies or contradictions, they turn their investigation around, and other times they never even interview the alleged suspect. Police records sometimes show very little evidence to back up the false reporting charges. After Nicole tells her whole experience to Colangelo, she has to decide whether she wants to officially change her statement or not.
Detective Colan…:	Do you want to consult with your attorney?
Nicole Chase:	Can I do that?
Detective Colan…:	Sure.
Nicole Chase:	I just want to make sure that I might even still have a chance at least of getting some type of justice.
Rachel de Leon:	Three weeks after her interview with Colangelo, Nicole goes back to the station. She’s there to officially revise her statement and turn in printouts of texts which Colangelo asked her for. A dispatcher tells her Colangelo’s busy and he’ll reach out if he needs her. She never hears back from him and emails the detective twice to follow up. By this time, Colangelo has already submitted a warrant for her arrest and when he finally emails her back, he doesn’t tell her that. It’s been two and a half months since Nicole has told Detective Colangelo the full story. She gets a call from him, and she can’t believe what she’s hearing.
Nicole Chase:	You have a warrant out for arrest, you need to come into the station. And I just held that phone and in my head, I have no idea what a warrant for my arrest is for because I haven’t done anything wrong.
Rachel de Leon:	The charge, making a false statement to a police officer. She turns herself in later that day.
Speaker 1:	Nicole started out as a victim reporting an alleged crime to the police. Then a detective lied to her and now she’s being charged for lying to him. When we come back, Nicole fights back. That’s next on Reveal.
	From the Center for Investigative Reporting in PRX, this is Reveal. I’m Al Letson. We’ve been talking about the police investigation into a report of sexual assault, but this isn’t your typical case. What makes it stand out is who the police arrested, not the alleged perpetrator...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Reveal News is a nonprofit organization focusing on investigative journalism. Their articles are usually well-researched and cover a range of social issues, including those relevant to law enforcement and social justice. Due to their investigative nature, they are credible, but as with all independent media, verification is necessary for claims made. Thus, it receives a high, but not perfect, score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence focuses on police investigation stories about sexual assault reports and does not address the Marquez case or provide any useful information about the identities and affiliations of the suspects involved.

content.content:
Government Misconduct and Convicting the Innocent 
The Role of Prosecutors, Police and Other Law Enforcement 
Page i • National Registry o f Exonerations • September 1, 2020 
# Government Misconduct and 
# Convicting the Innocent 
Samuel R. Gross, Senior Edito r, srgross@umich.edu 
Maurice J. Possley, Senior Researcher 
Kaitlin Jackson Roll, Research Scholar (2014 -2016) 
Klara Huber Stephens, Denise Foderaro Research Scholar (2016 -2020) 
NATIONAL REGISTRY OF EXONERATIONS 
SEPTEMBER 1, 2020 
# The Role of Prosecutors, Police and Other Law Enforcement 
National Registry of Exonerations 
Newkirk Center for Science & Society • University of California Irvine • Irvine, California 92697 
University of Michigan Law School • Michigan State University College of Law Government Misconduct and Convicting the Innocent 
The Role of Prosecutors, Police and Other Law Enforcement 
Page ii • National Registry o f Exonerations • September 1, 2020 
For Denise Foderaro and Frank Quattrone Government Misconduct and Convicting the Innocent      
> The Role of Prosecutors, Police and Other Law Enforcement
> Page iii •National Registry o f Exonerations •September 1, 2020
# Preface 
This is a report about the role of official misconduct in the conviction of innocent people. We 
discuss cases that are listed in the National Registry of Exoneration s, an on going online archive 
that includes all known exonerations in the United States since 1989, 2,663 as of this writing. 
This Report describes official misconduct in the first 2,400 exone rations in th e Registry, those 
posted by February 27, 2019. 
In general, we classify a case as an “exoneration” if a person who was convicted of a crime is 
officially and completely cleared based on new evidence of innocence. A more detailed definition 
appe ars here .
The Report is limited to misconduct by government officials that contributed to the false 
convictions of defendants who were later exonerated —misconduct that distorts the evide...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The University of Michigan Law School website is associated with a notable institution offering legal education and resources. It provides valuable legal knowledge, research, and insights from legal scholars. Though it primarily serves an educational function rather than real-time news, its scholarly content is grounded in legal standards, contributing to its credibility. The score is slightly lower because it may not provide direct news articles or investigative reporting.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This is a report about government misconduct in the wrongful conviction of innocent individuals. It does not provide any information regarding the suspects in Marquez's case or their identities and affiliations, making it irrelevant.

Query2.title: Decorated Marine attacked by group of teens outside D.C. McDonald's
Query2.snippet: Feb 17, 2016 ... Veteran Marine Sgt. Christopher Marquez, shown here in South Korea, was recently assaulted. A veteran Marine sergeant was assaulted and robbed ...

content.content:
!
A veteran Marine sergeant was assaulted and robbed at a McDonald's in Washington D.C. 
Police in Washington, D.C., are looking for at least four people in connection with the assault and robbery of Christopher Marquez, a Bronze Star recipient, who was one of two Marines who helped carry then-1st Sgt. Bradley Kasal out of Fallujah’s infamous “Hell House.”
Marquez, who served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011, told police he was assaulted on Friday around 10:30 p.m. while eating at a McDonald's, according to a Metropolitan Police Department report.
Marquez said he believes the attack was racially motivated. He remembers being accosted at the McDonald's in Washington's Chinatown neighborhood by five people between 16 and 21 years old. Most were men or boys. One may have been female.
“The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered,” Marquez said on Monday. “I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated. I felt how they approached me, it was very hostile. I felt they were really trying to intimidate me and just trying to start a confrontation with me.”
The police report does not include a description of the people involved with the incident, which was first reported by . One of the suspects allegedly hit Marquez with a gun after calling him a racist, the report says. Police have not yet made any arrests in the case, a spokesman said.
The suspects took Marquez’ wallet, identification...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a widely read national newspaper that covers a broad range of topics. It has established a reputation for providing balanced reporting and is subject to standards for journalistic integrity. However, at times it has been accused of producing superficial coverage in favor of broader appeal, which can affect depth. It remains a credible source overall, but with caution for deeper investigative claims.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides details about the number of individuals involved in the incident (at least four) and their actions but does not offer specific identities. It discusses Marquez's experience but doesn’t clarify who the attackers were or any affiliations, which somewhat lessens its relevance.

#### 
Decorated Marine vet attacked in D.C. McDonald's: 'Stop the racism'
===================================================================
By Jeff Schogol
 Feb 19, 2016
!:quality(70)/cloudfront-us-east-1.images.arcpublishing.com/archetype/56OD67PEUBBGROBV7OQCTPEPZ4.jpg)
The Marine Iraq War veteran decorated Marine who was assaulted and robbed outside a McDonald’s in Washington, D.C., McDonald’s wants everyone to stop using what happened to him as an excuse to inflame racial tensions.
Former Sgt. Christopher Marquez was knocked unconscious on Feb. 12 while leaving a restaurant in Chinatown. He told Marine Corps Times that prior to the attack, a group of people was very confrontational with him and asked him "if I think that black lives mattered."
Marquez, a Bronze Star with combat valor recipient, Mraquez said he does not condone people citing the attack on him to make racial slurs on social media. He also would like the Black Lives Matter movement to condemn what happened to him because he feels the mugging was racially motivated.
"Even though this was a racially motivated attack, more violence or hate is not the answer," Marquez said Thursday in an email to Marine Corps Times. "These people want to create more racism and division in our country because it serves their narrative. The best way to counter this cowardly movement is to be united and not divided."
Marquez said he strongly condemns any acts of retaliation and encourages people to have faith in the Washington DC police department and judicial system.
The police report of the Feb. 12 incident does not ascribe a motive to Marquez' attackers. In the brief narrative of events, police wrote that the suspects began to argue with Marquez and called him a racist. The police report quotes Marquez as responding by saying, "I am not even talking to you and that's your opinion."
Police released surveillance footage on Thursday showing three people they want to speak with in connection with the attack...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Marine Corps Times specializes in military news and analysis, and it is generally well-regarded for its accuracy and reliability concerning issues relevant to the military community. It typically employs experienced journalists with military backgrounds. Its focus on credible reporting makes it a solid source for news on military affairs, such as veterans’ issues.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article discusses Marquez's perspective on the attack and mentions the incident without providing specific identities of the suspects. It emphasizes Marquez's feelings and societal implications instead of focusing on the identities or affiliations, making it somewhat relevant but not highly informative for assessing the question.

The best way to counter this cowardly movement is to be united and not divided."

The police report of the Feb. 12 incident does not ascribe a motive to Marquez' attackers. QA.Question: What are the identities and affiliations of the suspects arrested for the assault on Marquez?
QA.Answer:
The identities and affiliations of the suspects arrested for the assault on Christopher Marquez are described in the following ways:

1. **Identities of the Suspects**: Two suspects, a 17-year-old girl and a 17-year-old boy, were charged in connection with the attack on Marquez. Police had been looking for at least four people in total linked to this incident, suggesting that others may have been involved. The attackers were described as teenagers, primarily male, with some reports suggesting at least one female was also present during the assault.

2. **Affiliations**: While Marquez claimed the attack involved racial overtones and he perceived it to relate to the Black Lives Matter movement—asserted when they confronted him about whether "black lives matter"—the police did not confirm any direct affiliations between the arrested suspects and organized movements like Black Lives Matter. The lack of confirmation regarding the suspects' ties to such movements indicates that while the interaction had a provocative racial element, it wasn't legally framed in that context, especially since they were not charged with hate crimes.

In summary, the suspects identified in the assault were two 17-year-olds, but further affiliations with the Black Lives Matter movement remain unsubstantiated by evidence.
